hero.title: MockCo — 2026 Pitch Analysis
hero.subtitle: A complete happy-path fixture for exercising the full dynamic report renderer.

cards.title: Growth quality
cards.summary: Net revenue retention has held above 120% for three quarters.

cards.title: Go-to-market
cards.summary: Expansion channel through implementation partners lowers CAC pressure.

cards.title: Product moat
cards.summary: Workflow data lock-in increases switching costs over time.

kv.Problem: Ops teams spend excess time reconciling fragmented business workflows.
kv.Solution: Unified orchestration layer that automates cross-tool handoffs.
kv.Business model: Seat + usage subscription with annual prepay discounts.
kv.Primary risk: Enterprise expansion cycles may slow in constrained macro periods.

lists.title: Open risks
items: Need to prove repeatability beyond design partners

triggers: Can net revenue retention remain above 115% post-scale?
How quickly does sales velocity change at 100+ customer count?
What percentage of onboarding still requires custom implementation?
Does product usage correlate with procurement renewal outcomes?
How defensible are integrations if incumbents ship native alternatives?
Is pipeline quality sustained without founder-led selling?
How sensitive is payback period to longer procurement cycles?
What security milestones are required for regulated buyers?

personas.name: Product-led Optimist
personas.summary: Sees early compounding signs from product adoption depth and low churn.
signals: High weekly active usage in power cohorts

personas.name: Enterprise Operator
personas.summary: Focuses on deployment complexity and services burden at scale.
signals: Security review pass rates trending upward

personas.name: Distribution Realist
personas.summary: Evaluates whether channel leverage can outpace direct sales costs.

personas.name: Unit Economics Skeptic
personas.summary: Wants clear proof that gross margin durability survives support overhead.
signals: Services ratio down with product maturity

personas.name: Platform Threat Watcher
personas.summary: Examines risk from bundled features offered by larger suites.
signals: Win rates hold against bundled alternatives

personas.name: Regulatory Pragmatist
personas.summary: Checks compliance posture for expansion into healthcare and fintech segments.
signals: SOC 2 and audit roadmap on schedule

personas.name: Talent Builder
personas.summary: Assesses ability to scale leadership and preserve product velocity.
signals: Recent VP hires from relevant scale environments

personas.name: Market Expansion Analyst
personas.summary: Tests adjacency assumptions before committing to category expansion.
signals: Cross-sell demand present in top accounts

personas.name: Risk-Adjusted Investor
personas.summary: Balances upside against concentration and execution dependencies.

personas.name: Contrarian Bear
personas.summary: Challenges assumptions around durability in a cyclical budget environment.

rounds.title: Round 1 — Opening positions
rounds.summary: Panel aligns that demand quality is real but debates moat durability.
points: Retention profile is above category average
Integrations are a strength but may commoditize
rounds.role_content:
Bull: The strongest signal is sustained expansion across cohorts, which usually predicts efficient growth if onboarding effort continues to fall.

Bear: Expansion can mask fragility when a small number of enthusiastic teams over-index usage. We still need evidence across slower-moving enterprise departments.

Wild Card: Both views are valid; the decision hinges on whether value capture remains tied to workflow criticality, not feature novelty.

rounds.title: Round 2 — Go-to-market stress test
rounds.summary: Debate centers on direct sales efficiency versus channel leverage.
points: Founder dependence in late-stage deals must decline
rounds.role_content:
Bull: Channel-assisted deals are closing faster and with less discounting, suggesting the product can be sold through trusted advisors.

Bear: Channel momentum can be cyclical and relationship-driven. If direct pipeline quality softens, growth could decelerate faster than expected.

Wild Card: Ask for cohort-level data split by channel origin to separate true efficiency gains from temporary tailwinds.

rounds.title: Round 3 — Moat and competition
points: Cross-tool orchestration depth may remain defensible
rounds.role_content:
Bull: Depth of orchestration across heterogeneous stacks remains non-trivial for larger suites to replicate quickly.

Bear: Incumbents can underprice and absorb functionality, especially if buyers view this as a convenience layer.

Wild Card: A defensible moat likely depends on proprietary workflow telemetry and superior implementation velocity.

rounds.title: Round 4 — Execution plan
rounds.summary: The panel designs conditions for an evidence-based investment.
points: Operational KPIs should gate follow-on capital
rounds.role_content:
Bull: Structure the check around clear milestones tied to deployment efficiency and net retention.

Bear: Include downside protections if enterprise cycles stretch materially or if services burden rises unexpectedly.

Wild Card: Require a monthly dashboard with implementation hours, churn attribution, and pipeline conversion by segment.

rounds.title: Round 5 — Final conditional verdicts
rounds.summary: Panel converges on a conditional invest with explicit guardrails.
rounds.role_content:
Bull: Invest now while category leadership is still contestable; momentum indicators justify early conviction.

Bear: Invest only if downside controls are contractually clear and there is no surprise deterioration in gross margin profile.

Wild Card: Consensus supports action, but only with explicit milestone governance and rapid response plans for execution drift.

stage_4.summary: MockCo shows strong early product-market fit and credible expansion dynamics, with manageable execution risk under milestone governance.
insights: Retention quality is the strongest leading indicator for long-term compounding.
Channel leverage can improve efficiency if direct pipeline discipline remains intact.
Moat durability depends on workflow depth, not connector count.
Execution risk is concentrated in onboarding and support efficiency.
Milestone-based deployment can preserve upside while constraining downside.
questions: Which customer cohorts sustain expansion without heavy services involvement?
What are the earliest warning indicators of bundling-driven churn?
How quickly can security and compliance maturity unlock higher-ACV segments?
What proportion of deals close without founder participation?
How resilient is demand under procurement slowdowns?
plans: Instrument a weekly retention and expansion dashboard by segment.
Codify channel qualification criteria and attribution standards.
Run competitive win/loss interviews each month for six months.
Gate headcount increases on implementation productivity targets.
Re-underwrite economics after two quarters using standardized cohorts.

epilogue.context: Illustrative projected ARR opportunity under a base-case five-year scenario if retention, expansion, and channel efficiency remain on current trajectory.
